awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Conference: 2022 Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace PI Meeting
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports development of the program for a 2-day workshop to bring together PIs from across the Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program. Specific objectives of the PI meeting include:

- to stimulate coordination and collaboration amongst SaTC PIs working on different projects;
- to foster new collaborations between SaTC researchers and researchers in other disciplines;
- to share experiences and learn from others' experiences in transitioning research into practice; and
- to develop ideas and share methods for improving education, recruitment, and career development in cybersecurity.

Building a strong community among SaTC researchers helps identify new research topics, avoid duplication of existing research, and improve educational opportunities for graduate students.

Some elements of the meeting are structured so as to mitigate risks associated with the spread of COVID-19 or the virtual participation that its spread might necessitate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The “2022 SaTC PI Meeting” grant was to support a symposium that brought together the SaTC community as well as interested outsiders for a two-day event.  The focus was on building community, sharing research ideas and results, and developing new collaborations.  The primary objectives for the meeting were (1) to stimulate coordination and collaboration amongst SaTC PIs working on different projects, (2) disseminate key results and highlight interesting new focus areas for SaTC researchers, (3) to share experiences and learn from others’ experiences in transitioning research into practice, and (4) to develop ideas and share methods for improving education, recruitment, and career development in cybersecurity. A secondary goal for the PI meeting was to expose research by the SaTC program PIs to a wider community, including government and industry.

 

The event was held on June 1-2, 2022 at the Hyatt Regency Crystal City Hotel in Arlington, VA.  There were 484 registered participants.  The program consisted of five kinds of activities:

 

Keynotes – the event had three keynote speakers: Cindy Cohn (Electronic Frontier Foundation), Yi-Kai Liu (National Institute of Standards and Technology), and Renee DiResta (Stanford Internet Observatory).  These keynote speakers represented a variety of perspectives on technologies of interest to the SaTC community.

 

Panels – the event had three panels. Two of the panels discussed topics of wide concern to the SaTC community: (1) ethics in security research and (2) trends in offensive vs. defensive security research. The third panel was a retrospective of SaTC research, as the meeting marked the 10-year milestone of the SaTC program and 20 years of sustained funding in cybersecurity from NSF. Panelists were from a variety of backgrounds, institutions, and research areas.

 

Breakouts – the event included 14 breakout groups. Each group met for 1.5 hours on Day 1 to discuss research challenges and directions and then again for 1 hour on Day 2 to summarize the discussion. Day 2 also included report-back presentations from each breakout group to all meeting attendees. The slides and a written report for each breakout were posted on the public event website after the event. The breakout topic areas were solicited from the PI community. We received 44 topic idea submissions. We drew from these submissions, combining and generalizing the topics to create a diverse set of 14 breakout groups of high interest to attendees.

 

Poster sessions – the presentation of posters was split into five mini-poster sessions held during breaks and immediately after lunch. PIs were each assigned one of the five sessions to present their poster. All posters were displayed during the entire event, with posters physically arranged to maximize social distancing during poster presentations. 

 

BoF Session – the event included a Birds of a Feather session on Day 1, including nine different topics. Five of the topics were pre-arranged and drawn from community-solicited breakout topic suggestions. Four additional topics were suggested on-site by attendees.

 

A post-meeting survey was conducted.  The results showed broad satisfaction with the event, as indicated by a large majority of respondents rating the meeting Very Good (50) or Excellent (28), versus a small minority rating it only Good (7) or Fair (3).
